Dear Mr. Scheuer:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code Staff responsibilities.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation Allegation 1
The child has special needs and was evaluated via Sprout, the
agency's worker did not obtain a copy of that evaluation report or
a copy of the child's neurological report and the therapy reports.
Allegation 2
The agency worker did not inform the child's Day Care provider
that the child is a temporary court ward. Due to that failure one
day the facility released the child to the birth mother who is not
approved for unsupervised visits with the child.
Investigation Allegation 1
Interviews
Complainant
One 8/2/2024 I interviewed Complainant by telephone.
Complainant affirmed the allegations in the complaint and
indicated clarifications. Complainant reported Child A’s prior
placement agency did not get Child A’s April 2024 Sprout Early
On report and Child A’s current case worker, Foster Care Worker
(FCW), failed to obtain a copy of that report for this special needs
child. She reported the Sprout evaluation indicated a neurological
was needed, and FCW did not follow up on that. She reported
Child A (age 3) only had the neurological exam that was just prior
to his placement with his father, Parent C. Complainant reported
Child A’s placement with Parent C is one the GAL (Guardian Ad
Litem) is in disagreement with and is appealing the court’s
decision on. Complainant reported FCW said she requested the
Sprout report and was told she needed a subpoena to get the
report. Complainant reported she is not sure when FCW would
have made that request. Complainant reported nor did FCW send
Child A’s mother, Parent B’s, therapist reports to the GAL and
2

Court for review and FCW was not drug testing Parent B. She
reported the GAL does not have the neurological or therapist
reports for Parent B, who is the one in therapy.
Foster Care Supervisor (FSC)
On 8/7/2024, I interviewed FCS by telephone. FSC reported in
August of 2023, the court dismissed the case against Parent C
and placed Child A in Parent C’s custody. FCS said when the
Department of Health and Human Services- Oakland County
(DHHS-OC) sends the court report and other supporting
documents to the Court they also copy those to the GAL, Parent
B’s attorney, and the Assistant Prosecuting Attorney (APA). She
reported reports were obtained for Parent B and sent to the Court
for the July 2024 court hearing. She reported the therapeutic
progress report for Parent B have been provided to the GAL, and
the Court for each review court hearing. She reported drug
screen results for Parent B have also been provided. FCS
reported she actually submitted the documents for the court
hearing in July 2024, and she sent them to the GAL. She said two
emails were sent to the Court and copied to the other parties. One
email contained the court report and the other email the social file
with the therapy reports and drug testing. FCS reported only the
GAL has complained about not getting these reports. She
provided me a copy of emails sent to the stated parties showing
the submissions.
FCS did not provide details related to Child A’s Sprout evaluation
report and or neurology report. She reported FCW had worked on
those and would have obtained or provided the information
available.
Foster Care Worker (FCW)
On 8/23/2024 I interviewed FCW by telephone. FCW said the
Sprout evaluation was over a year ago and completed when Child
A was placed via Wolverine and prior to Child A’s direct placement
with DHHS-OC. She reported not having a copy of that evaluative
report and trying to obtain a copy from Parent C. She did not
obtain a copy from Wolverine but reported discussing the
evaluation outcome with the Wolverine worker. FCW reported the
GAL never requested a copy of this report, nor reported she did
not have it. The GAL just asked whether she had reviewed the
Sprout report. FCW indicated she shared what she had obtained
about the outcome of the Sprout evaluation from the Wolverine
worker with the Court, and GAL at the court hearing. She said the
Court did not have a problem with that, only the GAL. She said
she reviewed Child A’s last neurological report, which was related
3

to his first appointment and that was also dated over a year ago.
The neurologist who authored the neurological report dismissed
Child A from further treatment. She said the Court did not have a
concern with her reporting on that matter either. She said the
GAL mentioned Child A’s behavior of head banging and she
shared Child A has not had that behavior since the prior two
incidents in foster care, and the one at school last year. She said
the GAL’s concern was that FCW didn’t have the original report
and that the report which FCW received via text from
Grandmother had not yet been uploaded to MISACWIS.
FCW reported when she received the case from Wolverine that
agency was following up on a referral related to the neurological
and the agency sent her the original report, and the last report,
which was the same and was for termination of any further
treatment. FCW said everything that was recommended, speech
therapy, special education she followed up on. She reported Child
A received those services. She said Parent C wanted additional
speech therapy and that is pending for Parent C to follow up on.
FCW reported having and providing Parent B’s therapy progress
reports and drug screens to the Court, GAL and others via email
on 7/5/2024, as an attachment with a court report. She also sent
documents to the GAL on 6/18/2024. She provided me copy of
those emails which was the same provided by FCS.
Documents Reviewed
Child A MISACWIS case record which showed:
• He entered care and was made a temporary court ward on
1/13/2021. He was placed in an unlicensed relative home
and two prior foster homes before his placement with
Parent C on 8/11/2023.
• A copy of a neurological report dated 10/10/2023 that
indicated it was for Child A, a new patient. This document
denoted it was a” Final Report”. That the diagnosis was
expressive language disorder. It indicated no concern for
Autism based on Parent C and Grandmother reporting and
their indication of a past evaluation. Additionally, this
neurological indicated no concern for the reported injury to
Child A’s forehead at that time and there was no concern
for sequala (after affect disease). The recommendation was
for Parent C to follow through with the additional speech
therapy Parent C indicated wanting.
Emails of reports sent to the Court, GAL and others dated
4/2/2024; for a 4/3/2024 court hearing; 6/18/2024 for a 6/24/2024
4

court hearing; and 6/27/2024 and 7/5/2025 for a 7/8/2024 court
hearing and which showed:
• The court report for the respective court dates.
• Copies of October and November 2023 drug screens for
Parent B along with therapy progress reports for Parent B
from 1/8/2024 to 3/27/2024 attached with the 4/3/2024
court report.
• Copy of a 1/24/2024-4/22/2024 updated service plan
attached to the 7/5/2024 court report along with therapy
progress report for Parent B from 4/4/2024 to 6/20/2024;
and June 2024 drugs screens for Parent B. The 6/27/2024
email showed the court report for the 7/8/2024 court
hearing was sent to the Court and GAL on 6/27/2024.
Allegation 2
Interviews
Complainant
On 8/2/2024 I interviewed Complainant by telephone.
Complainant affirmed the information indicated in the complaint
alleging Child A’s temporary wardship status not being reported to
Child A’s Day Care Center (DCC). She reported the DCC was
under the impression Child A was placed in Parent C’s mother’s
custody. She reported because of the lack of reporting by the
agency, one day in May or June of 2024, the DCC released Child
A to Parent B. Complainant reported this is a problem, because
Parent B does not have approval for unsupervised visits with Child
A.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS).
On 8/7/2024, I interviewed FCS by telephone. FCS said their
agency, DHHS-OC (Department of Health and Human Services-
Oakland County) had made the DCC aware of Child A’s
temporary warship legal status. She said FCW had gone to the
DCC several times to pick up Child A, and so, the DCC knew
Child A was under the supervision of the department. FCS
admitted it may be likely there is not documentation showing those
contacts by FCW with the DCC.
FCS reported with regards to the alleged incident, they learned
about the incident one to two weeks after its June 2024
occurrence. The GAL mentioned it at the July 2024 court hearing.
FCS reported what was explained is that Parent B went to the
DCC to retrieve Child A and the DCC called Grandmother (Parent
C’s mother and backup care provider) related to whether to
release the child to Parent B. Grandmother told the DCC it was
5

okay to release Child A to Parent B, that Parent C was in the car.
The DCC staff did not check the car to verify Parent C’s presence.
Nor did they contact DHHS-OC. FCS reported it turned out the
person in the car with Parent B was a friend of Parent B’s not
Parent C. FCS was not sure why Grandmother had not reported
the truth. She thought Grandmother may not have known that was
not the truth at that time. FCS said the GAL had not reported this
concern to the agency prior to the July court hearing. She said
once the agency was made aware of this incident, FCW
addressed the matter with the DCC the next day by going to the
DCC. FCW advised the DCC they are not to release Child A to
Parent B or any unapproved person. FCW also addressed the
issue with Parent C and Grandmother. FCS reported Parent C
had been doing welling caring for Child A.
Foster Care Worker (FCW)
On 8/23/2024 I interviewed FCW by telephone. FCW reported it
was true Child A was released to Parent B by the DCC, but not
because they did not know Child A was in foster care. She said
the DCC reported not reaching out to FCW when they released
Child A to Parent B because FCW was not listed on the DCC’s
emergency contact list. FCW could not explain why the DCC
would not have had her information available on file. She was also
not sure whether there was a copy of a school /day care letter/
document on file that the agency would have provided to the DCC
related to Child A being in foster care. She said she had
previously provided her information to the DCC and so had Parent
C. She said she provided the DCC office worker another one of
her business cards. She also reiterated to them they need to
contact her if they are leery or unsure about releasing Child A to a
Parent/ Person, if they are unable to reach Parent C or
Grandmother.
Documents Reviewed
Child A’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
• Previously reported information about his placement and
wardship.
• A prior Wolverine educational placement form for Child A at
a prior Day Care only- not one for this DCC
• A 3/12/2024 social work contact showing FCW picked Child
A up from the DCC and transported him to a parent/child
visit.
Analysis Allegation 1:
Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence does
not show that the agency did not obtain the child’s neurological
6

report or did not provide the birth mother’s drug screens and
therapy reports to the GAL. Nor that the agency did not work
directly with the children, their families, and other relevant
individuals related to the development, implementation of the
service plan.
Allegation 2
Based on interviews and documents reviewed there is insufficient
evidence to show the agency had not been in contact with the
DCC related to Child A being in foster care. Social work contact
showed FCW picking up and transporting the child from the DCC.
Nor does the evidence show that the agency did not work directly
with the children, their families, and other relevant individuals
related to the development, implementation of the service plan.
Technical Assistance
The agency is apprised submitting an official form letter to the
DCC which contains Child A’s name, other relevant information
and the FCW’s/ agency’s contact information on that form that can
be filed in the Child A’s DCC record and a copy placed in the child
MISACWIS would prove beneficial in this instance.
Conclusion Violation Not Established.
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section (1) An agency shall develop a plan of visitation and family time for
Description each child in foster care consistent with the child's service plans,
as required by R 400.12419 and R 400.12420 to ensure the safety
and well-being of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency allowed the child's birth father a convicted felon and
drug user to be the designee to supervise the birth mother's
parenting times with the child. Additionally, the worker has not
obtained documentation about the visits from the birth father.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant
On 8/2/2024 I interviewed Complainant by telephone.
Complainant affirmed the allegations as indicated in the complaint.
She reported the agency had been allowing Parent C to supervise
7

Parent B’s parent/child visit since some time starting in April 2024.
The Complainant reported FCW admitted this at a court hearing.
Complainant expressed concern that due to Parent C’s criminal
and drug history, as well as Parent B’s drug history that Parent C
should not be the parent/child visitation designee. Complainant did
not indicate whether there was a prior court order indicating
Parent C, who has placement of Child A could not be the person
to supervise Parent B’s visits with Child A. Complainant
responded that at the last court hearing in July 2024, the Court put
in the court order that Parent C cannot be the designee for the
parent/child visits.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS).
On 8/7/2024, I interviewed FCS by telephone. FCS confirmed it
was correct that Parent C has a past criminal conviction and drug
use history. She reported the Court was aware of that past history
and approved Child A’s placement with Parent C notwithstanding
those past issues. She reported it was also true that Parent C was
supervising Parent B’s visitation with Child A in the home. She
reported this occurred after a court hearing in April 2024 where
the Court indicated parent/child visitation could be by DHHS or by
Designee. FCS said she and FCW discussed the matter and
thought that supervision was doable. That since the Court felt that
Parent C was safe for Child A to be placed with, the agency
thought Parent C providing the parent/child visitation supervision
would not be a problem. FCS reported they thought it was okay
since Grandmother was also a designee to supervise the
parent/child visits. FCS said Parent C had been taking proper care
of Child A and prior to the GAL bringing the matter up at this last
court hearing, the Court had not objected to Parent C being the
designee for visits. The Court had previously indicated they
trusted DHHS-OC’s discretion. FCS said at the hearing in July
2024 the GAL did not want Parent C as the designee and the
Court indicated Parent C cannot be the designee. They are
abiding by that court order.
FCS reported Parent C reports about the visits have been slow
and sporadic. She reported FCW has all the parenting times
entered in MISACWIS for June 2023 and FCW is entering July’s
visitation now. She said Parent B may visit Child A two-to-three
times a week and the visitation outcomes they have would be in
the court reports.
Foster Care Worker (FCW)
8

On 8/23/2024 I interviewed FCW by telephone. FCW affirmed
information as reported by FCS. She also admitted that there was
communication issues with Parent C related to obtaining
information from him on the outcome of the visitation between
Parent B and Child A. FCW said she reported this concern to the
Court at the June 2024 court hearing. FCW reported she did not
terminate Parent C from being the parent/child visitation designee
related to his repeated delays in providing her information about
those visits because, though she had to track him down, at times,
she was getting some things from Parent C later to update her.
Documents Reviewed:
A copy of a court order from a 4/3/2024 court hearing that
indicated:
• Child A is to remain in Parent C’s home.
• Supervised parenting time for Parent B by the agency or
designee. The order did not clarify who could be a
designee.
• A copy of court reports for 6/24/2024 and 7/8/2024
respective court hearings which indicated to the Court
Parent B’s parent/child visits with Child A were being
supervised by Parent C, with Grandmother as a backup.
A copy of a 7/8/2024 court order that denoted:
• Parenting time shall be supervised by MDHHS or it’s
designee and that Parent C cannot be that designee.
Child A’s MISACWIS file which showed:
• Parent/child visitation between Parent B and Child A at
Parent C’s home documented from 4/18/2024 to 7/23/2024
with some parent/child visits occurring three or more times
within the month.
• Extremely limited information or details about the
parent/child visitations, with a number of parent/child
visitation outcomes not being entered in MISACWIS for
over three weeks up to two months or more after the date
of the parent/child visitation. Details about the outcome of
the worker’s regular monthly home visits were also
frequently not described/documented.
Analysis Notwithstanding whether Parent C was appropriate to be the
parent/child designee, based on interviews and documents
reviewed, the evidence did not show the agency was in violation
of the court’s order related to that aspect of the allegation.
9

As it relates to the FCW obtaining documentation about the
parent/child visits from the birth father, the evidence showed this
has not been timely, consistent, or promptly documented as would
relate to the rule of ensuring the safety and wellbeing of the child.
Conclusion Violation Established.
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section (2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child, and
Description the foster parent, if applicable, in the child's placement at least
once every month.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The worker admitted at the review hearing that she has not had
face to face contact with the birth father, who has placement of the
child, in weeks.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant
On 8/2/2024 I interviewed Complainant by telephone.
Complainant reported at the court hearing on 7/8/2024, FCW said
she had not seen Child A and Parent C in weeks.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS).
On 8/7/2024, I interviewed FCS by telephone. FCS reported the
visitation requirements have always been that the worker was to
see the child and the child’s father/caregiver monthly and that is
what FCW has been doing. She reported following the 7/8/2024
court hearing where the court ordered twice monthly contacts,
FCW has not missed a home visit to Parent C’s home.
Foster Care Worker (FCW)
On 8/23/2024 I interviewed FCW by telephone. She denied the
allegation. She said she has not missed a single monthly home
visit. She admitted there had been at least one time that she has
gone out and Parent C was not there, and she completed the visit
with Grandmother and Child A.
Reviewed
Child A’s MISACWIS file which showed:
10

• Consistent monthly home visits to Parent C’s home with
him and Child A from January 2024 to August 2024 as
required.
Analysis The evidence does not support the allegation of no face- to face
contact by FCW with Parent C and Child A in weeks or at least
once monthly as required by the rule.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
As a result of the findings in this investigation, a corrective action plan is required.
